stealing, on the 17th of April , one saw, value 2 s. 6 d.; one square, value 3 s.; one rule, value 2 s., the goods of
Robert Baleham
, and one saw, value 5 s. , the goods of
Samuel Allaway
.

ROBERT MIDDLETON
. I am a carpenter. I was at Claremont-terrace, Islington
, about half-past twelve o'clock, when the rest of the men were at dinner. I saw the prisoner come to the back of the houses, go down a ladder into the area, pull his apron off, and go into the building; I and another carpenter secured him as he was coming out with the property.

RICHARD BALEHAM
. I left the tools in the building, they are mine.
Prisoner. I was out of work.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. J. Vaillant, Esq.

556.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , one pair of breeches, value 12 s. , the goods of
George Turner
.

MICHAEL TURNER
. I am nephew to Mr.
George Turner
, who is a pawnbroker , and lives in Lower John-street, Grosvenor-square
. On the 5th of April the prisoner came to the door, and staid looking at the breeches which hung there, he then unhooked them off the nail, but they still hung on a line. He went out and touched a woman, they both came together to the door, he took them off, and put them under the woman's shawl; she went off, and he came into the shop, and produced a pair of shoes to pledge. I ran by him, and caught the woman in Golden-square with the breeches; I brought her back, and made her produce them. I told her the prisoner was the man who took them. He still remained there, as he did not know I was gone after the woman. I went for an officer, and our foreman let the woman go.
Cross-examined by MR. NORTON. Q. He might have escaped - A. Yes, but he did not see me go out.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. Every word he has said is false. I went to pledge the shoes, he brought a woman in, and charged me with the robbery.
GUILTY . Aged 39.

Confined Six Months and
Whipped .
First Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

557.
MARGARET HOLLOWAY
was indicted for
stealing on the 14th of April , one gown, value 7 s.; one handkerchief, value 2 s.; one pair of shoes, value 6 d.; and one bonnet, value 6 d. , the goods of
Sarah Walker
.

SARAH WALKER
. I live in Elder-walk, Williams'-court, Islington
. The prisoner lodged ten days with me. On the 4th of April, at half-past four o'clock in the morning, I went to work in Norfolk-street, and left her asleep. I returned about eight o'clock in the evening, and missed these things off my box by the bed side - she was not at home then. She slept with me. She came home in a half an hour very much in liquor, and abused me very much - she had my bonnet on her head, and my shoes on her feet. I asked her where my things were, and told her if she had pledged them to give me the duplicates. She said she would not, but she would bring them home as she liked. I got a constable who took her. Some duplicates were found on her at the watch-house that related to my property.

CHARLES DOWNER
. I am servant to Mr. Thumbleby; who is a pawnbroker, and lives in Old-street-road. On the 4th of April, the prisoner pledged a gown for 18 d. She said it was her own, and she had had it seven years.

GEORGE STOEL
. I live with
James Drew
, a pawnbroker, in Clark's-place, Islington. I took two handkerchiefs in pledge for 16 d., on the 4th of April, from the prisoner. I knew her before.

JAMES FRANKLIN
. I searched the prisoner at the watch-house, and found the duplicates on her.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. She was in the habit of lending me things, and I took the liberty to take them as I wanted money.
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Transported for Seven Years .
First Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

558.
JOHN HOLDEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of April , one marble frieze, value 25 s. , the goods of
David Barnes
.

DAVID BARNES
. I am a surveyor , and live in Change-alley. This marble was taken from a house I had lately built in South-place, Moorfields
. I saw it between ten and eleven o'clock in the morning safe in the parlour - it was not fixed. I ordered Crisp to watch the premises, and found the prisoner in custody next day with it.

WILLIAM CRISP
. I am a stable-keeper. On the 15th of April, about six o'clock in the evening, I watched the premises till about ten at night. I saw a person come to the corner of the house - two persons came to the end of the building; then the man whom I saw at the corner came to them and gave a whistle. I saw the prisoner put something on his shoulder - he came across the street with the marble on his shoulder. I followed, collared him, and told him he had stolen it from the new building. He said he picked it up coming across Moorfields. I told him I saw him take it up at the corner of the building. Several more came up and said they saw him find it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found it lying in the fields, and brought it to the corner of the house to see what it was.
GUILTY . Aged 21.

Confined Six Months and
Whipped .
First Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

559.
WILLIAM GEORGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of April , one shirt, value 18 d., and one pair of stockings, value 6 d. , the goods of the Overseers of the Poor of the parish of Edmonton
.

JAMES HARDING
. I am master of the poorhouse at Edmonton
; the prisoner was a pauper in the house. On the 3d of April I missed a shirt and a pair of stockings, suspected the prisoner, and found them secreted in his room, where we lock him up every night. They were between the bed and the sacking - he was the only person who slept there.

JAMES MANN
. I am a pauper in the house; the prisoner slept in a place by himself. On the 3d of April I was looking out of the window, and saw him take the stockings off the line. I told my master, and he found the shirt and stockings in the prisoner's room.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years .
First Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

560.
JOHN HICKEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of March one handkerchief, value 2 s., the goods of
Henry Thornton
, the elder
, from the person of
Henry Thornton
, the younger
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

561.
MARY CLAYSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of March , one watch, value 20 s. , the goods of
William King
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury, before J. Vaillant, Esq.

562.
MARIA BISHOP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of February , from the person of
William Walker
, one coat, value 40 s.; one pocket-book, value 6 s.; one watch, value 26 s.; one key, value 2 d.; two lbs. of beef, value 1 s., and one 1 l. Bank note, his property .

WILLIAM WALKER
. I am a tobacconist , and live in Salter's-street, Cannon-street-road. On Saturday evening, the 25th of February, about seven o'clock, I went to market to buy some beef. About half-past ten o'clock I met this woman in High-street. Whitechapel - I was quite sober. She asked me to go home with her, which I did to Exeter-street
, up one pair of stairs - we got there about eleven o'clock, and I went to sleep - no one was there but her. I had my watch, key, and the beef at the time - the beef was taken up stairs, but not dressed. I had not been with any other woman that evening; the door was not bolted. When I awoke, about half-past three o'clock, she was gone. I found the watch, key, beef, and the coat at the watch-house.

ADAM CLEGG
. I am a watchman; my beat is in Essex-street, Whitechapel. I know the prisoner, and know the house she lived at. On the 26th of February, about three o'clock in the morning, I saw her coming out of Sugar loaf-court with something in her apron. I asked her what she had got? she said a blanket, but I saw it was a coat and a piece of beef, and stopped her - there was no watch found on her. When I had taken her to the watch-house we searched her room, but found nothing; the bed had not been laid upon. We afterwards went to a room in Sugar-loaf-court, where a companion of her's lodged, and found the prosecutor. We asked him if he had lost anything? he said he did not know. We asked him what clothes he had? he said a great coat and a body coat. As he was getting up he said he had lost his watch, went to the watch-house, and claimed the coat.

SIMON SOLOMON
. I was constable of the night; the prisoner was brought to the watch-house with the coat and beef, after which we went to the house in Sugarloaf-court, and found the prosecutor. He complained of having lost his watch and pocket-book with a note; he said the prisoner was the person who picked him up in the street. He did not appear drunk when we found him.

ADAM CLEGG
re-examined. I saw the prisoner come out of Sugarloaf-court.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. As I was coming home on Saturday night I met a woman who gave me the coat and piece of beef. The watchman stopped me, and took me to the watch-house.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

563.
THOMAS ANTHONY
was indicted for
embezzling the sum of 5 s. 8 3/4 d. , the monies of
George Wells
.

GEORGE WELLS
. I keep the Red Lion, St. John-street-road
; the prisoner came into my employ in November, as pot-boy and general servant . I used to trust him to receive small sums of my customers. I had a good character with him, and he lived three months with me.

ANN TREEBLE
. I live at No. 23, Goswell-street-road, and dealt with Mr. Wells. On the 21st of February I paid the prisoner 2 s. for beer; Mr. Wells came afterwards and enquired if had paid him any money. I told him I had. I paid him myself.

MARY LYTE
. I live with Mr. Hughes, at Sadler's Wells. I paid 3 s. 2 1/4 d. to the prisoner on the 21st of February, I saw Mr. Wells the same night, and told him I had paid it.

ANN COATES
. I live in Northampton-square. I was a customer of Mr. Wells's. I paid the prisoner 6 1/4 d. myself. I saw Mr. Wells three days after, and told him I had paid his servant.

GEORGE WELLS
re-examined. It was the duty of the prisoner to account to me for the money he had received, but he never did. He left me on the 21st of February, and left this letter (read) -

"My reasons for leaving you I dare not say, I have no fault to find - what money I owe you I will call and pay. I am obliged to fly for reasons. I have no doubt you will think harsh of me, and it will go as hard with me for so doing, but I dare not tell the reason."
Prisoner's Defence. I had not drawn my wages of my master; I was going to receive my prize-money to make the deficiency good.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Three Months .
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

564.
JOHN FITZGERALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , one watch, value 10 s.; two seals, value30 s., and one watch-key, value 5 s., the goods of
Robert Mayne
, from his person .

ROBERT MAYNE
. I live in the Kent-road, at the floorcloth manufactory. During the chairing of Sir
Francis Burdett
I attended two ladies to see the chairing in the Haymarket, about four o'clock in the afternoon, I left the ladies there in a coach, and went to Charing-cross on business; on my return, in about a quarter of an hour, a young man passed before me, and made a snatch at my watch - he got it - it had also two seals; I seized him immediately, and held him about half a minute, when I was surrounded by a gang of them. They took him from me after a great resistance. The prisoner bit my thumb; he is not the person who took my watch, but he was one of the party - there were about twelve of them; they came up immediately, and the prisoner bit my finger, which made it bleed freely. I called out for assistance, but there was such a gang of them that the people were afraid to come and help me. I kept hold of the prisoner - they turned out my pockets, and kicked me. I did not lose anything else.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. You were in the crowd - A. No, I was not in the crowd at all - it was in Cockspur-street
. I took the prisoner at the time. When I went before the Magistrate I only charged him with an assault, and through the solicitation of his father he was held to bail. After that I went before the Grand Jury, and preferred a charge of felony. I told them the same story I have told you.
Q. What is the reason, after you preferred a charge of assault, that you went before the Grand Jury - A. I heard that he was a bad character. I believe he was found at his own dwelling.
JURY. Q. Is the prisoner the man who bit your hand - A. Yes. He bit the hand that I held the other by, to induce me to let him go.

RICHARD HAYWARD
. I am an officer, and live in Coventry-court, Haymarket. I saw two men holding the prisoner, and calling for an officer. Mr. Mayne told me that he had been robbed by a gang - his hand was bit; they did not attempt to molest me. I said he had bit the gentleman's hand. He said the gentleman had nearly choaked him, and he bit him to make him let go.

Cross-examined. Q. It was all over before you came up - A. Yes. When the complaint was made at Marlborough-street Office, the prisoner was remanded for re-examination. He was charged with the same offence as he is now, but there was some little difference on the second examination. The prosecutor did not appear quite so sure of his being the man. He was, with the approbation of the prosecutor, committed into custody for an assault.
COURT. Q. Did he ever say that the man only struck him, or that he was one who attempted to rescue the other - A. He said he tried to rescue the other.

THOMAS GOOK
. The prosecutor came to Hicks's Hall and filed a bill for Grand Larceny. I was sent to take the prisoner into custody - he had not surrendered to his bail when he was apprehended. He said he supposed he should go for life. I was not present when he was first apprehended.
Prisoner's Defence. I was with my father; I went into the crowd, and was separated from him. I never struck Mr. Mayne; he took hold of me by the collar - I said
"You will strangle me!" and hit him to make him let go.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Life .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

565.
RICHARD SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of March , one copper, value 15 s. , the goods of
William Moore
.

WILLIAM MOORE
. I am a broker , and live in St. John-street, Smithfield
. On the 3d of March I lost a copper; it was on the cellar-flap under the bow window - I saw it safe in the morning, about eleven o'clock, on my return about nine at night it was gone. I found it at Hatton-garden office next day. I never saw the prisoner before.

WILLIAM AIRES
. I am fourteen years of age, and lived with Mr. Moore. Some person gave information, I went down Passing-alley, and saw the prisoner with the copper under his arm. I called Stop thief! and he dropped it; I picked it up and brought it home.

THOMAS SIMS
. I was in the employ of Mr. Moore. I was told the copper was taken, and went down Passing-alley, where I saw the prisoner with it. There was a person taller than himself with him. I ran after him, he turned down Badger-yard, and then into Berkley-street. The man went down Badger-yard. We found the prisoner behind a door - he had an apron on.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

HENRY MORGAN
. I am a patrol of St. Sepulchre's. The two lads told me that the prisoner was down Badger-yard. I found him there behind a door.
Prisoner's Defence. They never saw my face.

WILLIAM AIRES
re-examined. Q. Did you ever see the face of the prisoner - A. Yes, he turned round to see if we were near him.
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Confined Four Months , and
Whipped .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

566.
ANDREW BAXTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April , three handkerchiefs, value 9 s. , the goods of
Jacob King
.

OSBORNE SPENCER
. I live with Mr. King, who is a linen-draper , and lives at No. 111, Long-acre
. On the 14th of April, between eleven and twelve o'clock, the prisoner came into the shop, and asked to look at some black silk handkerchiefs; I shewed him some, he wished to see some smaller. He said he had not money sufficient, and would call on Monday and buy them; the price was 4 s. 6 d. While I was looking for the smaller ones he took the three handkerchiefs and put them into his breeches-pocket. I let him go out of the shop, then went after him immediately, and brought him back. He pulled them out of his pocket; they were all in a piece.

JOHN NEWMAN
. I was sent for to take charge of the prisoner and handkerchiefs.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never had them.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Three Months .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

567.
ROBERT WYBURN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of February , one shawl, value 5 s., and oneapron, value 6 d., the goods of
Peter Gray
, from the person of Mary, his wife
.
The prosecutrix did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

568.
JOHN STAPLETON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of March , one watch, value 20 s., and one handkerchief value 4 s. , the goods of
Isaac Medell
.

ANN MEDELL
. I am the wife of
Isaac Medell
, we live in Mourning-lane, Hackney
. On the 15th of March, between eleven and one o'clock, the watch was safe in a drawer in my room. I was out at work, returned about nine o'clock, and it was gone. I saw it afterwards at a pawnbroker's in Barbican.

ROBERT HUXSON
. I am a pawnbroker and live in Barbican. On the 15th of March, in the afternoon, the prisoner pledged the watch with me for 14 s. Mrs. Medell claimed it three or four days afterwards.

JOHN GARVA
. I am a constable of Hackney. I apprehended the prisoner on the 25th of March; I told him it was for stealing the watch, he made no reply.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

569.
SAMUEL SAUNDERS
and
JOHN STONE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of March , one 1 l. Bank note and 14 s. in monies numbered , the monies of
Charles Louis Francis Vercolme
.

C. L. F. VERCOLME. I am servant to the Rev. Mr. Lambert, of King-street, Portman-square. On the 7th of March, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, I had been in the City and was going home - it was quite dark. I went into a public-house in Barrett's-court, Edward-street, Portman-square
- I had then four 1 l. notes in a purse in my side-pocket, I changed one of the notes there. Saunders came and sat in the same box with me, I treated him with liquor - I do not know Stone. After I had changed and had some liquor I fell asleep; Saunders was sitting close by me. I do not know whether my coat was buttoned or not. When I awoke he was standing by the fire, which was some distance from the box. It is a small room - I did not see Stone. I called for some liquor,
Ann Hooper
said,
"You have no money." I was surprised, and said,
"I have no money!" She said,

"Go and ask the man with the broken nose (Saunders) for the money." I immediately went to him, and asked him for my money, he struck me in the mouth; I then told the landlady that I had been robbed, and called the watchman. Prendergrast came and took charge of Saunders. He was searched, he had 34 s. in silver and a 1 l. note - I did not mark the notes. He told Prendergrast that he had no money at all. I was quite sober.

ANTHONY CHAPMAN
. I live in Cumberland-street, Middlesex Hospital, and am a shoemaker. I was drinking in the house. I was not there when the prisoner came in - the prosecutor was not sitting by him. When I came in he appeared quite sober, and I saw Saunders drinking with him - I drank likewise with him, and we had not more than a pot of beer each. I was there when he lost his money, and was on the opposite side of the box. Saunders was the only one that sat on the same side with him, no other person could set next to him on the other side. Saunders was on the left side of Vercolme. I observed Vercolme get change at the bar, and did not see Stone; I must have seen him if he had been there.
Ann Hooper
was on the same side as me. I never saw Saunders doing anything with Mr. Vercolme's pocket. He slept about three-quarters of an hour. When he awoke, he said he would have some beer; Hooper said,
"you have no money." He said,

"No money! (feeling in his pocket,) who has got my money?" Hooper said that man with a broken nose had got his money. I did not hear Saunders say anything. I went away before the constable arrived. I did not hear anything said to Saunders repecting his having any money. There was no blow struck while I was there.

SAMUEL PRENDERGRAST
. I am a constable. I heard the cry of Watch! and went into the public-house. The prosecutor said (in the hearing of Saunders), he had been robbed; he said nothing to it. I asked him if he had any money, or had robbed the prosecutor? he said, No. Saunders was very much in liquor - he made some resistance, and denied robbing him. I found 34 s. in silver, and a 1 l. note in his fob, and 3 d. in copper. Stone was not in the house at the time to my knowledge.

Q. During the time was there any blow struck - A. The prosecutor's mouth was very much swollen and bleeding: and he accused the prisoner with giving him the blow.
Ann Hooper
has since absconded and cannot be found. I took up Stone in the same house in the evening, about half an hour after, and found nothing on him.

GEORGE DORRELL
. I am a brick-maker. I went with Mr. Pendergrast, but I did not hear what was said by
Ann Hooper
. The prosecutor accused Saunders of striking him, but he made no answer - he accused him of robbing him, and he denied it. Pendergrast asked him if he had any money, and he said No.

ANN PIERPOINT
. I keep the house. I saw the prosecutor come in about three o'clock, and he appeared to be intoxicated. I saw
Ann Hooper
and Saunders there in the course of the day. Vercolme got change at the bar when he came in - no one could see him from the taproom. About two hours afterwards, I heard he had lost his money - Saunders had been absent about an hour during the time.

SAUNDERS'S Defence. The prosecutor came in and was in liquor - he asked me if I would drink with him, and called for some gin. He went out with a woman of the town, and the man she lives with tumbled them out of the house. When he returned he called for another pot of beer, and laid his head down and went to sleep, and I never left the house more than five minutes. I had no money in my pocket but my own.
C. I. F. VERCOLME re-examined. Q. From the time you first came into the house did you go out with a woman - A. Yes. I did for a little while, and had my money after that.
NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.
TWENTY-THIRD DAY, FRIDAY, MAY 8.

570.
THOMAS SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of April , one deal plank, value 3 s. , the goods of
Thomas Robinson
.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am a son of
Thomas Robinson
. On the 17th of April, about seven o'clock in the morning, I secured the prisoner right opposite our yard, in Nelson-street
, with this plank. He said he was distressed, and appeared so. I made enquiry and believe it to be true.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Fined One Shilling, and Discharged .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

571.
ROBERT REYNOLDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of March , one pair of trowsers, value 5 s. , the goods of
James Cross
.

JOHN HUVE
. I live with
James Cross
, who keeps a clothes-shop , in Shoreditch
. On the 2d of March, as I was standing at the back of the shop, I saw a person looking in at the door - he passed by after looking in very hard, and another came, and did the same - a third came and looked towards the counter. They could not see me. I saw the third as he passed by point towards the window, then the prisoner ran into the door-way and tore down the trowsers - he was the fourth, three had passed by. I pursued him about fifty yards, laid hold of him, and he dropped it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

572.
JOHN RICHARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , part of one telescope, value 10 s. , the goods of
George Richardson
.

GEORGE RICHARDSON
. I live in Upper East Smithfield
, and am an optician - the telescope was in the window. The window had been broken before, and having been frequently robbed, I attached it by a piece of wire to a bell. I stopped the hole that had been made in the window by a compass box, and had so placed it that if it should be moved it would ring the bell - on the 30th of March, about half-past seven o'clock in the morning the bell rang - I was not down stairs at the time.

GEORGE PATRICK
. I live with Mr. Richardson, and was in the shop when the bell rang. I was aware of the bell, and then looked towards the window, and saw that some one had pushed the box aside. I saw the prisoner's hand in pulling out the telescope, I then went and took him about thirty yards from the window - he had it partly out, and I saw him with it. The telescope was at one side of the box, and it was removed about six inches from the place it was first in.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. There was a compass-box removed to make room for a persons hand - A. Yes; the telescope was removed six inches towards the hole. I saw the prisoner's face, and am quite sure that he was the lad that had his hand through the window - there were two other lads with him.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw two lads looking into a window, and after they were gone, two young men came and immediately charged me with taking the telescope. They took me to the shop, and he said
"I have caught you at last."
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Confined Three Months and
Whipped .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

573.
MARY LATCHFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March , one feather-bed, value 2 l.; one bolster, value 5 s.; two pillows, value 4 s.; one set of fire-irons, value 4 s.; one brass footman, value 2 s.; one looking-glass, value 4 s.; one tea-board, value 3 s.; one set of bed-furniture, value 18 s., and two blankets, value 4 s., the goods of
James Edwards
, in a lodging-room in the dwelling-house of the said
James Edwards
, let by contract, by him to the prisoner to be used with the lodging .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

574.
JAMES JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of March , one copper boiler, value 13 s. , the goods of
John Holten
.

JOHN HOLTEN
. I keep the Half-moon, Lower-street, Islington
. On the 1st of March, I lost a copper - it was hanging in the tap-room on a crane. I saw it there about a quarter of an hour before it was stolen. I saw the prisoner in the tap-room. I did not see him take it off the crane, but I saw him take it out of the house.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. It was at about eleven o'clock at night - there were two others taken up with him, the Grand Jury threw out the bill against them - I never saw them playing. Some dispersed and others remained - the boiler was found outside the door. I saw he prisoner with the boiler there.

JAMES HOWNDLEY
. I was called to take charge of three persons, but never saw the prisoner. I heard the copper fall, but did not see the spot where the boiler was dropped.

Prisoner's Defence. I went with three others, to the Half-Moon, and partook of some liquor, which not being accustomed to, it affected me, and we began playing, blacking each others' faces. On the 7th of March I was in bed, and they came and charged me with felony.
NOT GUILTY .
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

575.
MARY JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of March , five yards of linen, value 7 s. , the goods of
Henry Haskins
.

SARAH HASKINS
. I am the wife of
Henry Haskins
, who lives at No. 9, Paradise-row, Pancras
. I had the five yards of cloth to make two shirts with - it was up stairs - my father was lying dead at the time. The prisoner came to see him, and the cloth was there then; I saw it on the Wednesday, and did not miss it till Monday - I found it at the pawnbroker's.

EDWARD M'DONALD. I am servant to Mr. Button, who is a pawnbroker, and lives at No. 2, Battle-bridge. I received the piece of cloth in pledge from the prisoner on the 3d of March, and am quite sure she is the person.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was very much in distress. I meant to redeem it.
GUILTY . Aged 52.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged .
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

576.
ANN JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , one watch, value 2 l., and one seal, value 4 s. , the goods of
John Joseph
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

577.
MATTHEW HORRIGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of March , one shirt, value 2 s. , the goods of
George Barford
.

CHARLOTTE BARFORD
. I live in Gloucester-buildings, Whitecross-street
. I lost the shirt out of the yard on the 7th of March - it is a court-yard, and has no thoroughfare; I saw the prisoner in the yard, but never saw him before. I saw him break the line, take the shirt, and run away with it. I opened the door, ran after him, and saw him going into a coffee-shop with it under his arm. I got an officer, and found the shirt on the floor of the coffee-shop.

GEORGE MOORE
. I am a pipemaker. I was in Chequer-alley, by the coffee-shop, and saw the prisoner run into it with something under his jacket. Mrs. Barford overtook him going into the coffee-shop, and charged him with stealing the shirt.

JAMES HADLEY
. I was desired by Mrs. Barford to apprehend the prisoner - there were about twelve others in the room. When I went in I told all the persons to stand up, and she pointed out the prisoner as the lad. I found the shirt just under him, it was wet.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The woman and the constable came in, and pointed me out as the person without a hat; there were several others in the same room without hats.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Whipped and Discharged .
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

578.
MARY HILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of April , one coat, value 2 l., and one waistcoat, value 12 s. , the goods of
Frederick Schutt
and
John Hollings
.

JOHN HOLLINGS
. I am a tailor . On the 13th of April I left my house a little before six o'clock - the coat and waistcoat were safe then in the cutting room, which is the front parlour. The prisoner is a stranger. I was sent for home about seven o'clock.

MARY ANN SCHUTT
. I am the daughter of
Frederick Schutt
. On the 13th of April I was in the garden adjoining the house, which is in Ridinghouse-lane
. Between six and seven o'clock I heard some one walking in the passage, and perceived the prisoner coming out - the street-door is open for the accommodation of lodgers; she had these things under her shawl. I pursued her some distance, and brought her back with them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Confined Four Months .
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

579.
JOSEPH HARDING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February , one watch, value 4 l., and four seals, value 2 l., the goods of
James Davey
, from his person .

JAMES DAVEY
. I live in Harley-street, and am coachman to Mr. Mitchell. On the 4th of February, about half-past six o'clock, I was coming from Tottenham-court-road
; at the corner of Portland-place and Devonshire-street I saw two men coming, one was about five yards behind the other - one caught hold of my arm, and the other pulled my watch out instantly and ran away. I called out Stop thief! the other came, took hold of my arm, and asked what he had done? I told him he had taken my watch, and broke from him. He said

"Come along, I can run faster than you, and I will catch him." He ran a few yards, and then tripped up my heels - I am sure he is one of the two - the other came up the instant I had lost the watch. I never lost sight of the prisoner till he was stopped at the corner of Weymouth-street.

JOHN MAUD
. I am a gentleman's servant, and live in Portland-place, between Devonshire-street and Weymouth-street. I found the watch in the area on a Thursday, at the latter end of February, about nine o'clock in the evening - it had been thrown there.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN MARTIN
. I was officer of the night; the prisoner was brought to the watch-house by Oram, about half-past seven o'clock, Davey came down with him, and charged him with robbing him - he told the same story which he has now, and was quite sure the prisoner was one of them.
Prisoner's Defence. The man has sworn falsely.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Life .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Serjeant.

580.
PHILIP HYDE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of April , one bason, value 1 s., and one ewer, value 1 s. , the goods of
Francis Tadman
.

FRANCIS TADMAN
. I live in Old-street
. On the 12th of April, between nine and ten o'clock in the evening, I stood on the opposite side of the way, the prisoner and another came to the window and took the bason and ewer; I pursued and took him. He said,
"Have pity, for I am in distress."

THOMAS HOBBS
. I was standing nearly opposite the prosecutor's house, I heard the cry of Stop thief! and saw the prisoner with the things, the other got away.
Prisoner. I saw them on the second step of the door, and being in distress I took them.
GUILTY . Aged 28.

Confined Two Months and
Whipped .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Serjeant.

581.
JOHN GREGG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 6 lbs. of bacon, value 2 s. , the goods of
James Reynolds
, Sen
.

JAMES REYNOLDS
. I keep a cheesemonger's-shop
, in Brick-lane, Bethnal-green
. On Thursday, the 11th of April, about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, the bacon was on the stall-board.

JAMES REYNOLDS
, JUN. I am ten years old. I saw the prisoner take the bacon off the stall-board, and I called out, and went after him. I was knocked down by one of the party - I called out Stop thief! and he was stopped by a stranger; he dropped the bacon, and it was picked up by my father - there were five of them.

WILLIAM STOKES
. I am a watch-house keeper. The prisoner was delivered into my custody.
Prisoner. The prosecutor said that he would forgive me if I confessed it, which I did.
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Confined Two Months and
Whipped .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

582.
ATKINSON BUCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of March , one coal-tub, value 3 s. , the goods of
Edward Minton
.

RICHARD MINTON
. My father,
Edward Minton
, lives at No. 1, York-place Islington
, and the tub was inside of the house. The prisoner was brought into the shop with the tub.

WILLIAM BERGY
. I saw the prisoner take the tub. Suspecting him, I watched - he was lurking about the shop. I was three doors beyond it - there is a projection were the goods are exposed to sale, about three yards.

THOMAS FRANKLIN
. I took the prisoner into custody.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner. I did it from the want of employment. I was reduced to the most abject state of poverty; if you would take my case into your kind consideration, and by your assistance, I may become a worthy member of society.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Judgment Respited .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

583.
SAMUEL SPRINGETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of February , one coat, value 3 s., and one plane, value 2 s. , the goods of
David Roberts
.

DAVID ROBERTS
. I live in Long-lane, and am a carpenter . On the 23d of February, the coat and plane were stolen from me were I was at work, at the back part of Furnival's-inn
- they were inside of one of the houses. I went to get my dinner, and saw them when I came back in the custody of the gate-keeper with the prisoner.

GEORGE SIMPSON
. I am the gate-keeper. On Wednesday, the 23d of February, a few minutes before one o'clock, I saw the prisoner walking along with some shavings under his arm, coming from the back part of the building. I asked him who gave him the shavings? he said, a man had given them to him. I then saw part of a garment in the shavings, and asked him what he had got there? he said it was a jacket he had bought of a man. I detained him, and sent for the carpenters, and the prosecutor owned them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I was in great distress - I never broke my fast since Monday.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Judgment Respited .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.
